Text: Hear this, all you peoples; listen, all inhabitants of the world,
Context: This is an introduction calling for attention from all people regardless of their standing.

Text: both low and high, rich and poor alike:
Context: The Psalmist makes no distinction among his audience; his message is universal.

Text: My mouth will speak wisdom, and the meditation of my heart will bring understanding.
Context: The Psalmist claims to impart wisdom that comes from deep reflection and understanding.

Text: I will incline my ear to a proverb; I will express my riddle with the harp.
Context: The speaker is poised to deliver his message in a thoughtful and artistic manner, using a musical instrument.

Text: Why should I fear in times of trouble, when iniquity engulfs those who trust in their wealth?
Context: The verse reflects concern over misplaced trust in wealth, especially during difficult times.

Text: They have no power to redeem a brother or give to God a ransom for him—
Context: Here, the Psalmist emphasizes the limitations of wealth, as it cannot save a person's life.

Text: The ransom for a life is costly, no payment is ever enough—
Context: This verse echoes the sentiment that material wealth cannot redeem a human soul.

Text: that he should live on forever and not see decay.
Context: The finality of death contrasts with the inability of wealth to secure eternal life.

Text: For he sees that even the wise die; the fool and the senseless alike perish and leave their wealth to others.
Context: The inevitability of death is presented as a fact observed by the wise.

Text: Their graves are their eternal homes—their dwellings for endless generations—though they had named lands after themselves.
Context: Reflects the bitter irony that regardless of one’s earthly accomplishments, the grave is the final abode.

Text: But man cannot abide in his pomp; he is like the beasts that perish.
Context: Here the Psalmist equates the transience of human glory with the perishable nature of animals.

Text: This is the path of those who have foolish confidence; yet after them, people approve of their boasts. Selah
Context: The folly of misplaced confidence in wealth is highlighted, and a pause (Selah) for reflection is indicated.

Text: Do not be afraid when a man grows rich, when the splendor of his house increases;
Context: The Psalmist advises against envy or fear of those who amass wealth, suggesting it has no eternal value.

Text: For when he dies he will carry nothing away; his splendor will not descend with him.
Context: An admonishment that material wealth and glory are not carried into the afterlife.

Text: Though in his lifetime he blesses his soul—and men praise you when you prosper—he will join the generation of his fathers, who will never see the light of life.
Context: A reflection on the transient nature of human accolades and the inescapable reality of death.

Text: Man in his pomp, yet without understanding, is like the beasts that perish.
Context: A repetition of the sentiment that worldly prestige is meaningless without spiritual understanding.

Text: But God will redeem my soul from the realm of the dead; He will surely take me to Himself. Selah
Context: A declaration of confidence in God's salvation and a subsequent pause (Selah) for contemplation.

Text: Do not be overawed when a man grows rich, when the splendor of his house increases;
Context: The Psalmist further advises not to be intimidated or impressed by the accumulation of another’s wealth.

Text: For he will take nothing with him when he dies; his splendor will not follow him down.
Context: Further emphasizes the point that death is the great equalizer; no one can take their wealth with them.

Text: Though while he lived he counted himself blessed—and men praise you when you prosper—
Context: A reflection on the empty nature of self-praise and the congratulations of others in light of the inevitability of death.

Text: he will join the generation of his fathers, who will never see the light.
Context: A sober acknowledgement of the destiny awaiting every person after death.

Text: Man in his pomp but without understanding is like the beasts that perish.
Context: Reiterates the message that earthly glory is meaningless without true wisdom, and thus, without understanding, one's fate is no different from animals.
